title: Boston police now required to wear nametags under new contract extension
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Boston police patrol officers are now required to wear nametags under a new contract extension with the city.
The contract, ratified last week, includes wage increases, free gym access, and a performance evaluation system for officers.
Mayor Michelle Wu emphasized transparency and public trust; the contract covers a one-year period costing approximately $6.7 million.

title: The backlash has arrived: 6 takeaways from a good night for Democrats
author: Reid J. Epstein, The New York Times
bullets: Democrats won significant elections in Virginia, New Jersey, California, and Pennsylvania, marking a rebuke of Trump and Republican policies.
Abigail Spanberger's and Mikie Sherrill's victories in Virginia and New Jersey focused on criticizing Trump's policies, signaling Democratic momentum.
Zohran Mamdani, a progressive, won New York City's mayoral race, showcasing an alternative Democratic vision and strategic approach.

title: The Swedish candy craze has taken Boston by storm. Here’s where you can get it.
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: Swedish candy craze in Boston was sparked by a viral TikTok, leading to the opening of several candy shops.
Madeleine's Candy Shop, The Sweetish Fish, and lil sweet treat offer unique Swedish candies lacking gluten, corn syrup, and trans fat.
Madeleine's Candy Shop features 50 pick-and-mix bins, while The Sweetish Fish offers changing selections and lil sweet treat adjusts varieties weekly.

title: Few answers as Woburn-based Newpro files for bankruptcy after sudden shutdown
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Newpro, a Woburn-based home improvement company, abruptly closed on October 28, leaving employees and customers without answers.
The company and its subsidiaries, under Renovo Home Partners, filed for bankruptcy in Delaware, affecting people nationwide.
The company's assets are reported between $10 million to $50 million; a creditors' meeting is scheduled for December 12.

title: Snag 20% off JetBlue flights in December during this limited-time sale
author: Kristi Palma
bullets: JetBlue offers 20% off base fares during a two-day sale ending November 6 for December travel.
The discount applies to flights from December 2-18 but excludes Friday and Sunday travel.
Additional up to 40% off on round-trip flights as part of JetBlue Vacations packages for travel through March 2026.

title: WWII veteran’s remains are being returned to Weymouth
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: WWII veteran Alfred Thomas Langevin's remains return to Weymouth after 81 years, identified via DNA analysis.
Langevin was reported missing in November 1944 during the Battle of Hürtgen Forest in Germany.
Public services in Weymouth include a viewing on Sunday and burial on Monday with full military honors.

title: Embattled Everett mayor loses reelection bid to city councilor
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Robert Van Campen unseats Carlo DeMaria as Everett mayor, ending DeMaria's nearly 18-year tenure.
DeMaria's administration faced controversy over $180,000 in longevity payments and past allegations of sexual harassment.
Van Campen's campaign focused on accountability, transparency, and addressing school overcrowding and traffic congestion.

title: ‘The sun is up and we’re fighting’: Bill O’Brien’s fiery response to question about Boston College football
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: Bill O'Brien defends Boston College football's resilience despite a 1-8 record, citing team spirit and ongoing competition.
During a press conference, O'Brien criticized media negativity and emphasized the program's long-term building effort.
Boston College has three games left, ending the season against Syracuse; O'Brien's future as head coach is uncertain.

title: Apparently, Mass. had a ‘gustnado’ touch down Monday night — and more wind is coming
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: Massachusetts experienced a 'gustnado' Monday; small whirlwinds were reported during thunderstorm outflows.
Wind gusts between 55-65 mph expected in Southern New England from Wednesday night to Thursday morning.
Wind speeds could reach 70-75 mph near Provincetown, potentially causing tree damage and power outages.

title: Trio sought in alleged unprovoked Halloween attack at downtown T station
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: MBTA police are searching for three suspects involved in an unprovoked Halloween attack at State Street station.
The assault occurred around 11 p.m. on Halloween at the State Street MBTA station.
Authorities have released surveillance photos and urge anyone with information to contact MBTA police at 617-222-1050.
